tabData.tagHTML: Jainism places great emphasis on the thought process, as actions are a reflection of our thoughts. To achieve equanimity and self-control, Jainism recommends meditating on twelve specific reflections known as Bhävanä or Anuprekshä. These reflections on the fundamental facts of life help us see the world as it truly is, free from delusion. Practicing Bhävanäs can stop the influx of new karma and help shed old karma.
There are twelve main Bhävanäs and four auxiliary Bhävanäs that support the five main vows.

tabData.title: The Twelve Main Reflections
tabData.description: Contemplating these twelve facts of life helps in achieving detachment and spiritual progress.

cards.back: Impermanence: Reflecting that all external things, including our body, are temporary and perishable. Only the soul is eternal.
Helplessness: Realizing that worldly things like wealth and family cannot protect us from disease, old age, and death. True refuge is only in the Dharma.
Cycle of Birth and Death: Contemplating the endless cycle of birth and death, filled with pain and misery, to inspire a desire for liberation.
Solitariness: Reflecting that the soul comes into the world alone, leaves alone, and bears the fruit of its own karma alone.
Otherness of the Body: Realizing that the soul is separate from the physical body, which is mortal and impure.
Impurity of the Body: Reflecting on the impure nature of the body to lessen our attachment to it and its pleasures.
Influx of Karma: Thinking about the ways karmic matter flows into the soul through passions and unrestrained actions.
Stoppage of Karma: Contemplating on the ways to block the influx of new karma, such as self-control and discipline.
Eradication of Karma: Reflecting on the twelve types of austerities (Tap) that help shed accumulated karma.
Nature of the Cosmos: Contemplating the vastness of the universe and its six substances to dissolve pride and ego.
Rarity of Enlightenment: Reflecting on how difficult it is to attain a human birth and the teachings of the Jina, inspiring us to make the most of this opportunity.
Rarity of True Religion: Contemplating the difficulty of finding a true preceptor (Guru) and understanding the true nature of Dharma.

tabData.title: The Four Compassionate Reflections
tabData.description: These four reflections help develop purity of thought and sincerity in daily life.

cards.back: Contemplation of Friendship: Cultivating a feeling of friendship and goodwill towards all living beings.
Contemplation of Appreciation: Admiring the good qualities and success of others, thereby destroying jealousy.
Contemplation of Compassion: Feeling sympathy and kindness for those who are suffering, weak, or in distress, and helping them.
Contemplation of Neutrality: Remaining neutral and uninvolved with those who refuse to follow the right path, avoiding anger and frustration.
